_exec_summary.SummaryText:
Accidental Release Prevention Policy:

Protecting and responsibly managing natural resources demonstrates stewardship and is critical to the quality of life in the communities we serve, to the environment, and to WTG Jameson, L.P. (WTG's) long-term business success.  Promoting the health and safety of co-workers, contractors, customers, and communities is the responsibility of all WTG employees.  WTG will meet all applicable laws, rules, and regulations.



Stationary Source and Regulated Substances Handled:

Jameson Gas Plant ("Jameson"), located in Silver, Coke County, Texas, is a natural gas treating, processing and fractionation plant.  Inlet gas enters the plant from intermediate pressure field gathering stations.  Jameson treats, processes, and fractionates flammable gas and liquid mixtures in an amount greater than the threshold quantify containing any of the following RMP-regulated constituents:

?    Methane

?    Ethane

?    Propane

?    Isobutane

?    Butane

?    Isopentane

?    Pentane

The only RMP-regulated toxic constituent present at Jameson, which is part of the amine treating process, is hydrogen sulfide; however, quantities at this facility are well below the threshold quantity. 



Accidental Release Prevention and Emergency Response Policies:

WTG is committed to ensuring a safe work environment for all its employees, contractors, and vendors.  The Jameson Gas Plant has a detailed Emergency Action Plan and has coordinated with the community's local responders through mock emergency simulations to introduce the local responders to the facility and its personnel.



General Accidental Release Prevention Program:

The Jameson process is covered by OSHA 29 CFR 1910.119, Process Safety Management of highly hazardous chemicals (PSM) regulation.  WTG considers the systems developed for compliance with PSM to be the basis for good safety and business practices.  In this effort, WTG identifies opportunities to continuously improve initiatives for each PSM element.  The

PSM elements are implemented to satisfy the PSM/RMP requirements since the Jameson Gas Plant qualifies as a program level 3 RMP process.



Employee Participation:

Employee participation is the foundation block to an evergreen and integrated PSM program.  Thus, the current PSM improvement initiative is heavily focused on this key element as employees are becoming more actively involved in the implementation of each element of PSM.



Process Safety Information:

Comprehensive reviews of the available process safety information (PSI) have been conducted.  Updates to maximum intended inventory (MII), piping and instrumentation diagrams (P&IDs), area classifications, and material balances have been completed.  A comprehensive electronic web-based system utilized for timely access to information has been built, implemented, and made available to all personnel involved with operating the process.  



Process Hazard Analysis (PHA):

A new PHA team including experienced operating personnel (operations and maintenance), WTG engineers, Process Control personnel, safety representatives, and PSM representatives conducted a PHA revalidation from June 10, 2019 through July 26, 2019.  A final report was completed December 16, 2019 and has been reviewed by all pertinent parties.  Results and recommendations from PHA analyses have been actively shared with employees.  Additionally, a process safety tracking tool is used for the interactive tracking of PHA action items to closure.



Operating Procedures:

Written operating procedures with references to pertinent PSI are available and were most recently updated as of November 20, 2020.  A written mentorship training program has been developed, implemented, and documented per employee.  A technical review of operating procedures is currently underway while also being formatted into a standard operating procedures format across WTG will be completed.  WTG will also be publishing operating procedures to the company's electronic web-b

ased system.



Management of Change (MOC) and Pre-Startup Safety Review (PSSR):

Improvements to the MOC procedure and associated checklists are in progress to capture all process related changes and ensure a more efficient system.  Requirements for the identification, evaluation, control, and authorization of modifications to plant design and operations prior to the implementation to ensure that the risk of new or existing hazards are properly managed is available to all personnel.  Extensive PSSR checklists for applicable disciplines (electrical, instrumentation, procedures, etc.) have been developed and implemented.  The MOC documents and checklists are available online from the company's electronic web-based process library. 



Mechanical Integrity (MI):

A complete third-party MI gap assessment has been completed and updates implemented to Jameson's MI program.  The updates are based on revised comprehensive company inspection standards and procedures along with a specialized inspection program structured specifically for Jameson using Recognized and Generally Accepted Good Engineering Practices (RAGAGEP) and meeting American Petroleum Institute (API) requirements.



Incident Investigation:

WTG investigates all PSM incidents.  Throughout the PSM program assessment process, incident investigation procedures are being reviewed and will be updated, as necessary.  A mix of WTG personnel will be provided investigation methodology training to further enhance the program and ensure root cause is consistently identified.  A process safety tracking tool is used to track action items and incident investigation corrective actions to closure.



Compliance Audits:

To meet compliance with PSM/RMP, WTG conducts compliance audits every three years to verify all PSM/RMP element requirements are being satisfied.  In WTG's general PSM/RMP improvement program initiatives, an updated audit protocol has been established and implemented within WTG.  





Hot Work Permit:

Hot

work permits are in use and on file.  These permits are maintained in the plant control room.  Throughout the PSM program assessment process, the hot work procedure will be reviewed and will be updated, as necessary.



Contractors:

WTG has an electronic program for contractors that includes their safety records.  A review of the contractor's safety record both prior to selection and during their time of employment is conducted.



Training:

With the enhancement of various PSM elements such as PSI, PHAs, operating procedures, PSSR, MI, MOC, incident investigations, etc., additional training (computer and classroom based) has been established to ensure all Jameson employees are knowledgeable in these processes.



Chemical Specific Prevention Steps:

The process at Jameson has hazards that must be managed for continued safe operation.  Following is a description of existing safety features applicable to prevention of accidental releases of regulated substances in the facility.



Universal Prevention Activities

The accident prevention program summarized previously is applied to the RMP-covered process at Jameson.  Collectively, these prevention program activities help prevent potential accident scenarios that could be caused by equipment failures and human errors.



Specialized Safety Features:



The Jameson Gas Plant has safety features on many units to help:

I.    contain/control a release

II.    quickly detect a release; and

III.    reduce the consequences of (mitigate) a release.

Release Detection

I.    Hydrocarbon detectors with alarms located throughout the process along with automatic shutoff of natural gas compressors

II.    Fire eyes located within each compressor building and connected to the automatic shutoff of the natural gas compressors 

III.    Remote emergency shutdown for all inlet gas pipeline valves

IV.    Hydrogen sulfide detectors with alarms located in designated process areas

V.    Routine operator rounds/equipment inspections

VI.    Operators are on-site

continually (8,760 hours per year)



Release containment/control measures include:

I.    Main process relief valves that discharge to a flare to capture and incinerate episodic releases

II.    Automated and manual valves to permit isolation of the process

III.    Automated shutdown systems for specific process parameters (e.g., high temperature)

IV.    Curbing to contain liquid releases

V.    Redundant equipment and instrumentation (e.g., uninterruptible power supply for process control system)

VI.    Atmospheric relief devices.



Release mitigation measures include:

I.    Fire extinguishing systems

II.    Personnel trained in emergency action

III.    Personal protective equipment (e.g., chemical protective clothing, self-contained breathing apparatus)



Emergency Response Program:

The overall emergency response program for Jameson has been coordinated with the Coke County LEPC.  Several local emergency responders that support Jameson include Robert Lee Volunteer Fire Department and Emergency Medical Services; Colorado City Emergency Medical Services; Coke County, Coleman County, Nolan County, and Runnels County Sheriff; and Coleman, Colorado City, and San Angelo Department of Public Safety.  The Jameson Gas Plant has around-the-clock communications capability with appropriate emergency response organizations (e.g., fire department, Police and Sheriff's office).  This interface provides the means of notifying the public of an incident, if necessary, as well as facilitating quick response to an incident.  Jameson will conduct its first mock emergency drill with the LEPC and emergency response organizations in 2021.  The facility will conduct additional emergency drills annually with local emergency responders regarding the hazards of regulated substances in the facility.



Five-Year Accident History:

All incidents that occurred within the previous five years were reviewed to determine whether any are subject to RMP reporting.  There have been no accidental releases of regulated

substances meeting the accident reporting criteria of 40 CFR 68.42(a).

Planned Changes to Improve Safety

WTG Jameson will continue to improve its safety and environmental performance through emphasis on the continued development of its PSM Program.  Improvement plans include process engineering support to update critical PSI data for the site; operating procedures written for each mode of operation and to include consequences of deviations; an operator certification training program established from the new operating procedures, new process hazard analysis (PHA) procedure and team structure ensuring employee involvement, new MI program incorporating the implementation of all new inspection procedures and frequencies all to be carefully reviewed, and recommendations for improvement generated using WTG's new compliance audit process.
